awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Factoring User Behavior into Network Security Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will investigate human factors in network security. The security of network systems relies on proper protection from not only known vulnerabilities, but also new vulnerabilities resulting from unexpected human behavior. The project will directly address a user's situational behavior and its consequence on network security. It engages in the challenges of modeling decision-making process and integrating it in the human-network interaction. If the user's behavior can be predicted and its impact on network vulnerability can be estimated, the network manager can effectively close vulnerabilities and avoid grave security breaches.  This will change the view of a network as a static infrastructure and security holes as design flaws of the infrastructure, and it will regard humans as an integral factor in network security.

The project involves theoretical and experimental study from behavioral science and research methodology from computer science and statistics in modeling the decision-making process. It uses the model to predict user behavior when the user's psychological state and network variables have changed, which would greatly assist the network manager to attain an up-to-date assessment of network vulnerability.  The work includes three thrusts: 1) a theoretical framework for studying human cyber behavior, 2) experimental study on human subjects in a cyber environment, and 3) comprehensive human-network system-level vulnerability analysis. The major outcome of this project is an integrated framework to include human factors in network vulnerability analysis.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to study the human factor in network security. The vulnerability of a network system not only exists in the design of the software and hardware systems, but also arises from end user’s cyber behavior. Successful identification of human-induced vulnerabilities is the key to improve system design towards future robust and resilient network systems.

Experiments have been conducted to study the effect of human-computer interface (HCI) design on users’ risk taking behavior. The study reveals that HCI design does, to some degree, affect a user’s cognition and perception of security or risk. For instance, in web design, priming is more effective than negative framing to reduce cybersecurity risks faced by users.

HCI design also affect users’ perceived possible loss or expected gain. Experiments have been conducted to test that between utility theory and prospect theory, which one is applicable to user’s cyber behavior and to what degree; between avoiding a loss and receiving a gain, which one serves as a better incentive; with probable loss (or gain) and guaranteed loss (or gain), how user perceives it and reacts to it. It is concluded that a user’s willingness to engage in risky behavior is not a simple linear function of the probability of gain (or loss). These are two factors that cannot be summed up to cancel each other.

The outcomes of the project support the viewpoint that human behavior is a contributing factor to network security. Network security breach is not only a design flaw of the infrastructure, but also a result of human-system interaction. The project advanced our understanding of network and information security, and fostered STEM workforce development in the crucial area of cyber security.
